result.query:
Please find the name of the catalyst and co-catalyst name from the provided context which describe an solar chemical experiment.
Please only generate the name of the catalyst and nothing else. Such as TiO2. ZrO2 or Ag, etc.
Please generating restrictively follow the format, and must start the generation as the format. Do not generate anything else.
If there are multiple results, please indicate them as XXX-XXX.
catalyst: XXX
co_catalyst: XXX

evidence.pdf_reference: The photocatalytic CO 2 reduction experiment was carried out in a homemade stainless vessel reactor with H 2 O vapor under visible light irradiation ( 420 nm).Before the catalytic reaction, and the trace impurities in CO 2 (CO and O 2 ) was removed by Cu and CuO at 650 C.50 mg catalyst powder was evenly dispersed in the reactor tray.Prior to light irradiation, the reactor was rinsed with CO 2 (30 mLmin) for 1 h at 160 C to remove the air in the reactor and the organic substances adsorbed on the catalyst

adsorbed on the catalyst surface.Then, all the valves of the reactor were closed to form a sealed system.0.3 mL deionized water was injected into reactor.Subsequently, the 300 W xenon lamp (PLS-SXE 300C xenon lamp) equipped with a 420 nm cutoff filter was used as the simulated light source.After irradiated at 160 C for 2 h, the products were analyzed by an on-line gas chromatography using a thermal conductivity detector (Agilent 4890, nitrogen as carrier gas).

samples was evaluated by temperature programmed desorption (TPD-CO 2 ).0.3 g catalyst samples were filled in a quartz tube and purged with nitrogen at 773 K for 2 h.After the reactor was cooled to a specific temperature, the CO 2 was introduced in the way of pulse to achieve a saturation chemisorption.Following, the samples was purged with He gas to the equilibrium, and the temperature was increased to 500 C at the rate of 5 Cmin.The desorbed products were measured by TCD detector. The photocatalytic CO 2

sample may have highest photocatalytic activity as compared with other samples.The optical response and photoelectrical chemical properties of the as-prepared samples were tested by electrochemical workstation.Fig. 9(a) showed the transient photocurrent response under 10 cycles of Xeon lamp irradiation equipped with a 420 nm cutoff filter.As can be seen in Fig. 9(a), all samples displayed photocurrent response under visible light irradiation, and photocurrent firstly increased gradually, then decreased

were performed using an electrochemical workstation (CHI-650E, Chenhua Company, Shanghai, China) with a three-electrode system.The test was conducted at room temperature using 0.1 molL Na 2 SO 4 as electrolyte solution.The as-prepared samples electrodes on the ITO glass were served as the working electrode.The AgAgCl electrode acted as the reference electrode and platinum sheet worked as the counter electrode, respectively. The CO 2 chemical adsorption ability of as-prepared samples was evaluated by

result.query:
Please find the category of Light_source and Lamp from the provided context which describe an solar chemical experiment.
The generation condition of the extraction is given: If Light_source is Solar or Solar Simulator, Lamp is always Solar Simulator.
Please only select the generation from the provided possible choices.
Possible Choices:
Light_source: ['UV', 'Solar', 'UV-Vis', 'Monochromatic', 'Solar Simulator']
Lamp: ['Fluorescent', 'Mercury', 'Halogen', 'Mercury-Xenon', 'LED', 'Tungsten', 'Xenon', 'Tungsten-Halide', 'Solar Simulator']
Please generating restrictively follow the format, and must start the generation as the format. Do not generate anything else.
Light_source: XXX
Lamp: XXX

evidence.pdf_reference: adsorbed on the catalyst surface.Then, all the valves of the reactor were closed to form a sealed system.0.3 mL deionized water was injected into reactor.Subsequently, the 300 W xenon lamp (PLS-SXE 300C xenon lamp) equipped with a 420 nm cutoff filter was used as the simulated light source.After irradiated at 160 C for 2 h, the products were analyzed by an on-line gas chromatography using a thermal conductivity detector (Agilent 4890, nitrogen as carrier gas).

All the chemical reagents used in the work were analytical grade and not further treated before the experiments.0.02 mol Ferric nitrate and 0.01 mol magnesium nitrate were dissolved into 300 mL deionized water under stirring to form a transparent solution, then this solution was dropped into 3 molL NaOH solution with a stirring.The pH of mixture was adjusted to 10 by using aqueous ammonia.After being stirred for 12 h, the suspension was filtered and washed several times with deionized water to remove Na ,

The photocatalytic CO 2

were performed using an electrochemical workstation (CHI-650E, Chenhua Company, Shanghai, China) with a three-electrode system.The test was conducted at room temperature using 0.1 molL Na 2 SO 4 as electrolyte solution.The as-prepared samples electrodes on the ITO glass were served as the working electrode.The AgAgCl electrode acted as the reference electrode and platinum sheet worked as the counter electrode, respectively. were measured using an American Quantachrome Autosorb analyzer at -196 C.Prior to the analysis, all of the samples were vacuumed at 200 C for 6 h.The surface area and pore volume were calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method.The valence states of elements were obtained by an X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS).The oxygen vacancies were determined by electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy (EPR) with a Brook a300.
